Hi All,
Hope you are doing well!

We are facing issue when creating new list by using API endpoint

We are using the below API endpoint to create a new list in our HubSpot account.
- <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/lists/create_list>

Previously this API endpoint was creating a new list in our HubSpot account successfully but now it's returning a response like the below when creating a new list:
*- list_permission_issue*

We have shared this in the community but we couldn't get a solution.

Could you please help us to resolve this issue?

I’m still wondering what’s the difference between having a dev account with a certain theme and creating a sandbox from a live account… You have to replicate everything on the latter one! I don’t see any benefit compared to a dev account :shrug:

<https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mclarenjon_HubSpot-HubSpotcli-HubSpottipsandtricks-activity-6848272264757178368-iKve?utm_source=linkedin_share&utm_medium=member_desktop_web|If you can use FTP, you can use the HubSpot CLI.> If you’ve put off learning the CLI, I recommend diving in now. Hello! I'm pretty new to HubSpot development and wanted to know: is it usual to use themes from the marketplace (free and bought) to build from, I'm guessing with a child theme, using existing and making own templates and modules for clients? Or do you always start with the boilerplate?

I am now managing 5 different themes, all of which share about 80%+ similar codebase, mainly differing in the modules, sections and templates each one ships with - and I looking for a better version control system.

For example: I need to be able to make updates that are relevant to all themes (eg: a bugfixs or global module updates) but also need to be able to manage theme specific features + updates that may not pertain to the other themes (eg: updates to a module that exists in Theme 3, but not in Theme 1 or Theme 2)

I'm exploring the idea of using a single repo with branches for each theme, or multiple repos for each theme that all form a type of "boilerplate" - but haven't really found a system that feels 100% right just yet.

*Can anyone share a version control system* they've implemented which works well for managing multiple ( themes | sites | projects ) that all share mostly the same codebase? Or if anyone else is looking to solve the same issue and has some good ideas I'd be happy to brainstorm.
